messages: 0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (13:39): You know, I can't help but think that the best way forward for Microsoft is to release their HTML 5 browser as a completely separate product. Make it have a new UA string, make it not respond to IE conditional comments (give it newname conditional comments if absolutely necessary), make it have a new navigator.useragent string. Effectively making this product a new entrant into the market....
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (13:39): ...Position it as the upgrade path, but don't force that upgrade.

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (13:39): Customers shouldn't do worse with it then with Firefox, while still having the option to use "old-IE" for legacy IE-only intranet apps. And it's not as if Microsoft hasn't done this before - just think of their ERP products.
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (13:39): s/then/than/ (meh)
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (13:42): I wonder if they'd ever buy into that line of reasoning...
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (13:53): 0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3, I agree with you. MS (or other vendor) should be able to build a whole new UA, for HTML5
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (13:55): (that is what I hope to see next... a Mozilla branch for HTML5 only)
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (13:55): it would easily become one of the reference implementation
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (13:57): *cough* to "easily" :)

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:01): f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6: it wouldn't be necessary for Mozilla (or any other non-IE browser), as IE is the only one which is as consistently targeted by workarounds for bugs. Mozilla should just be able to follow the HTML5 specification and use it to render all of the current web as well.
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:02): 0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3, the problem is that in that case MS could only "follow", I think.
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:03): but, I'm not very into it

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:03): and it wouldn't be a whole new UA for MS - it would be mostly the same rendering engine (assuming it can be extended and fixed to do HTML 5) - but just not responding to any of the current hacks anymore (and not needing to, as they'd be just as right at implementing the specs as everyone else)

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:04): they'd even still do activeX and all their other extensions, so a lot of apps which exist right now as IE-only - but in a standards-compatible way - would continue to work.
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:04): I really think they would better start from scratch.
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:05): (given what they did not in IE7)
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:05): they won't. They'll take one look at how long it took Mozilla, and consider it (rightly so) a bad idea to start from scratch.

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:06): However, what I'm proposing would give them far more leeway to make radical changes than they had in IE7, as IE7 responded to most of the same workarounds IE6 did, and so had to remain compatible with them.
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:06): but they have Avalon, now
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:06): One of the reasons it took so long for Mozilla to start from scratch is because there was no spec that described how to implement a browser for the web
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:07): see one of chris' early message where he wrote that it'd have been better for IE7 if it would've just been sent the same content as gecko got.

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:08): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: that's not the impression I've gotten from hearing the Mozilla devs talk about it. (Brought up recently again in the whole Mozilla 2 discussion - let me see if I can find the relevant post.)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:08): I'm sure much of their time would have been spent reverse engineering IE and NN4
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:09): did not they started from a "netscape5" codebase?
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:09): that is what I remember
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:09): partly, yes, but a lot of it was rewritten
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:09): f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6: they did, and then scrathed the whole rendering engine in favour of "NGLayout", which later become gecko
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:10): that was a great decision for the web, but the effective death-knell for Netscape (remember Netscape 6?)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:11): NN6 was definately a welcomed improvement over NN4, but it far too unstable
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:12): for MS, I think one way could be to hack some XAML renderer
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:12): a "XAML to Web Control" converter for example
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:13): (it could be even a OSS project)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:13): what does XAML have to do with the web?
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:13): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, XAML is the "unified" MS langauge for describing UI
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:13): yeah, I know that
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:14): I'm wondering what the relevance is
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:14): I'm just pondering loudly :)
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:15): I see some overlaps... just have to figure out better

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:16): (Hmm, that mozilla 2 discussion post that I was thinking of wasn't very clear on that subject; probably only seemed so to me as I remembered earlier references.)
f6a47a638824180d57f0a561fd5843c6 (14:22): btw, I think MS think XAML has *much* to do with web. But I'm really not a .NET person

d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (14:34): maybe it should be a design principal that we don't care about incompetents :)
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (14:34): course, i'd feel unloved then
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:36): We don't really have to worry about the developers who write quirks mode pages, because quirks mode is already frozen

0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:36): I don't think it'd be physically possible to both keep backward compatibility and make the language have a high chance of being used right by "incompetents". So, we shouldn't let their needs dictate what HTML 5 will look like - but we should still remember their existence, and - all other things being equal - choose the way that will make things easier for them.
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (14:36): Otherwise we end up with incomprehensible and totally impossible to code for a novice things like XHTML namespaces.

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (14:40): I don't understand how people can be so elitist. There is no reason why anyone should not be able to create a web page. It provides access to a publishing medium to millions of people with low literacy. If someone wants to code it like a pro and know about things like the DOM, good for them. I know my mom doesn't but I still think she should be able to code her own page.
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (14:41): hates to use his mom as an example, because CW has also been using his mom as an example, but my mom is actually taking a web design course this week
